--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> More importantly, if a phenotypes doesn't develop
> properly
> it won't be chosen to reproduce anyway since it's
> fitness
> will be so low.  

This is probably the key point.  Even if we had an
artificial evolutionary model with indirect encoding
and a relatively long and complex developmental phase
before the phenotype was capable of eliciting the
desired behavior, those that didn't develop properly
would be weeded out.  

> I don't see this as a problem.  In principle,
> anything
> in nature could be theoretically mated as well.  We
> could line up the genes based on the best possible 
> analysis and then construct a new genome based on
> the
> hybrid.  But usually hybrids between different
> species 
> would have very low fitness (more likely no fitness
> at 
> all).  The point is, where nature draws the line is 
> itself arbitrary in the sense that it is just a side
> effect of a conglomeration of complex and
> happenstance 
> factors that causes species to avoid each other.

Right, which was all my basic point really was: that
real-world reproduction is based on phenotypic
compatibility.  

You're right that since all biological organisms use
the same DNA, just in different lengths and sequences,
they're as theoretically compatible as NEAT
chromosomes.  We've already done some of this
artifical mating (spider silk genes spliced into cows
so that their milk contains spider silk, jellyfish
genes into monkeys so that their fur glows in the
dark).

> But physical morphology is a proxy for
> genetic compatibility.  In fact it is likely worse
> since it's only an estimate!  Nature doesn't have
> access 
> to historical data on genes so it has to do its best
> with what it has.  

But it is nature's way of speciating, which as you
point out may not be optimal.  I'd tend to agree.  

> I guess there is some room for debate.  But I doubt
> any biologist thinks a single amino acid mutation
> can
> create a new species that is both fit and
> genetically
> incompatible with humans.

No, I don't think anybody would argue that.  The
debate is over the relative impact that single
mutations can have, either positively or negatively
affecting fitness.  

> I'm not sure.  If the phenotypoe is tolerant to
> mutation
> why not experiment with high mutation rates since it
> likely won't screw anything up?  But I think the
> question
> is open and a good question.

I would tend to think that in indirect encoding
schemes, measures that reduce the impact of single
mutations would be more desirable.

For example, even in NEAT's direct encoding scheme,
the way you handle adding a neuron is deliberately
aimed at reducing the initial impact of the mutation,
right?

I would think this sort of thinking would be even more
important in cases where a single mutation might
affect the phenotype more profoundly.

> I looked into this once.  Miscarriages are not all
> caused
> by mutations, but those that are I believe are small
> percentage, but still they do exist.  

After some informal poking around on the net, in
humans the rate of miscarriage for confirmed
pregancies seems to be between 10-20% (and there are
many miscarriages that occur well before women are
even aware they're pregnant).

Of those, a couple of different sources estimated that
50-60% of miscarriages were due to genetic faults in
the developing embryo or miscombinations of
chromosomal DNA between the sperm and egg.

> But what does
> this
> have to do with genetic compatibility?  The
> miscarriages
> aren't a new species.  They're just a nonfunctioning
> system.  Their genomes are still "human".

Whether that's true I think is a matter of some
debate, but they're obviously so unfit that they'll
never be potential mates, so as you indicate, the
point is moot.

> I agree.  It's will be interesting to experiment
> with
> different methods.  I don't mean to imply we
> shouldn't
> explore the way we compute thresholds and normalize
> for
> compatibility.  All I am saying is that these
> computations
> should be genotype-based.

Yeah, I tend to agree with you.  Nature doesn't work
this way, but I think this is most probably a case
where it makes much more sense to diverge from
real-world analogy.

> Yes I follow you...way down the line maybe we can
> simulate the whole deal, down to the cells or even
> atoms.  Then we wouldn't have to do any speciation
> computations of our own.  Of course, what we would
> have to do would be far more complex and difficult.
> But who knows..maybe .someday...

We'd only need to capture and simulate the features
that are necessary to achieve our goals, and I'm not
sure simulation down to the cellular or atomic level
is necessary to do so.

But who knows? :)

> For what it's worth, I've taken graduate level
> neuroscience, 
> graduate level biological evolution and development,
> (a.k.a. evodo),
> and several other courses on evolution.  But it
> would
> be cool if anyone else here has their own biological
> expertise
> as Derek is asking?

Most of my education on such matters is informal, and
I'm guessing by the relative silence that most people
here are CS people, though they'd have to have at
least some knowledge/interest in biology, evolution,
psychology, and neuroscience to be here in the first
place.

Derek
